Introduction

This policy document is the response of the Estates and Facilities Department to meet requirements and commitments regarding the Safe Management and Use of Non-medical, Pathology and Industrial Gases and to comply with the Gas Safety (Installation and Use) Regulations 1998.

The use made of the various types of non-medical gases within the Trust is widespread. The use varies from the cooking of food, heating of premises and providing hot water and steam to operational uses in both the Pathology and Engineering Departments.
Scope
The purpose of this document is to:
To ensure the safe use of all gases.
To ensure the safe and proper storage of gases.
To make sure adequate training is given to all gas users on the proper care required and known hazards associated with the various types of gases.
To limit the use of various gases to persons who are authorised as competent to care and manage such gases.
Definitions

table_items.text: Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust

data.text: Role and responsibilities within the Trust
The Chief Executive of Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust will ensure that all the premises entrusted to the Estates and Facilities Department will comply with all statutes.
The Line Managers/Supervisors are at all times directly responsible for ensuring that day to day safe methods of working, safe conditions of work and a healthy work environment exist.
Employees General Duties
Co-operate with the Estates and Facilities Department so far as is necessary to enable any duty placed on the Directorate by the Gas Safety (Installation and Use) Regulations 1998.
Employees specific duties
Every employee who has to work with gas must:-
Take all reasonable steps to prevent leakage or escape of gas.
Ensure NO SMOKING rule is rigidly adhered to.
All sources of ignition are extinguished.
Not search for escapes using naked flames.
Test for gas tightness any affected part of the system.
Report all defects or suspected defects in the gas system.
Adhere to Permit to Work systems.
Adhere to Procedure Notes.
Procedure for the safe management and use of non-medical,
pathology and industrial gases
Guidance

The discovery of gases and their usage has contributed greatly in improving our lives and the quality of medical care being provided. However, experience has shown that coupled with all advancements and benefits to day to day living come serious hazards that can occur if people are not careful in making use of the beneficial nature of the various gases properly.

The leakage of various gases can be flammable, asphyxiant, anaesthetic, toxic, corrosive or a combination of these. In the event of a leakage, gas may collect in a confined space causing or contributing to a fire, explosion or hazard to health.
Legislation - natural gas services and appliances
The Gas Safety (Installation and Use) Regulations 1998

The Regulations require standards of competency and care that seek to ensure that all persons are protected from personal injury, fire, explosion or other damage arising from the use of gas supplied, from pipes so far as is reasonably practicable.
Duties and responsibilities

Where a Manager or Building Occupier of any Trust premises knows or has any reason to suspect that gas is escaping into their premises, that person shall immediately take all reasonable steps to shut off the gas at such a location as is necessary to prevent any further escape. If gas should continue to escape into the premises or should a smell of gas persist, the Manager or Occupier should immediately give notice to the supplier of the gas to the said premises. Where an escape of gas has been stopped by such actions, no-one shall cause or permit the supply to be re-opened until all necessary steps have been taken to prevent gas escaping again.

No person shall undertake any work relative to a gas fitting/installation unless they are competent to do so. Proof of competency is best achieved through the ‘Gas Safe' registration scheme. Alternatively the requirements for demonstrating competency are detailed in the Approved Code of Practice (ACOP) for standards of training in safe gas installations available from the Health & Safety Executive.
The employer of any person carrying put such work, should ensure that they are competent and the provisions of the gas regulations are complied with.
General safety requirements
No person should carry out work in relation to a gas fitting unless it is undertaken:-
In a proper and workmanlike manner;
In a manner designed to prevent any escape of gas unless steps are taken to prevent an escape of gas that constitutes a danger to persons and/or property.

In a manner so ordered as to ensure that no incomplete gas way is left unsealed if the work is left unattended. Fittings used for gas way seals should be appropriate and be gas tight or otherwise makes the gas fitting safe. If any pipe or fitting becomes disconnected, every outlet of every pipe should be properly sealed.
When any work is undertaken in relation to a gas fitting or pipe:-
Smoking is prohibited;

All sources of ignition such as blowlamps or pilot flames must be extinguished until such time as the system has been purged or sealed and the surrounding area made safe from risk of fire or explosion.
NO source of ignition should be used when searching for any escape of gas.

Where the likelihood exists of any work affecting the tightness of the system, the affected part of the system should be tested for gas tightness at least as far as the nearest valves both upstream and downstream of the ‘fitting', the affected parts should be examined for compliance with the regulations. On domestic installations this will require testing of the complete system.

Prior to any gas fitting or pipework being returned to service after being opened to the atmosphere, all affected parts should be purged to remove safely all air and any gas other than the supply gas.
Installers of any gas fitting should ensure that:-
Every part is correctly supported and positioned or protected so as to avoid undue risk of damage.

Where there is any reason to suspect that gas ways or airways may possibly be blocked by loose foreign matter that is likely to interfere with the safe operation of the fitting, suitable filters or other protection must be provided.
Gas fittings are not to be installed where they are likely to be exposed to corrosive substances unless they are made from materials not subject to such corrosion.

All alterations to premises containing a gas fitting should be carried out in such a way as to ensure that, had the fitting been installed after the alteration, the gas regulations would be complied with, without contravention.

No work should be undertaken that would affect a gas fitting, any flue or other means of ventilation that in such a way is likely to make any subsequent use of any gas fittings, dangerous to either persons or property.

Any work that involves breaking the earth continuity of a gas pipe should only be undertaken after a suitable temporary electrical earth connection has been made to maintain earth continuity until the pipe work is reinstated.
Work on gas installations
Materials
No gas fitting should be installed unless every part is of sound construction and of adequate strength and size to ensure safety at all times.
No pipe shall be installed in a building for the supply of gas that is made of lead/lead alloy or of a non-metallic substance unless it is non-metallic:-
Where it is a pipe connected to a readily moveable gas appliance designed for use without a flue i.e. a Bunsen burner, brazing torch etc.

Where it is a pipe entering a building and is placed inside a gas tight metallic sheath that will so far as is reasonably practicable, prevent an escape of gas into the building if the pipe should fail.
Emergency controls

The Manager of any Trust building has a duty of care when permitting persons to have occupancy of their buildings, to instruct them on the emergency procedures to isolate the gas supply and for the evacuation of the building.

All new gas installations in any building or dwelling shall be provided with an emergency control (valve) as near as is reasonably practicable to the point of entry. The valve may be inside or accessible outside of the building or dwelling. A service (supply), a meter valve or an additional valve may be used as the emergency control.

The emergency control valve shall be securely fitted with a key or lever that is parallel with the flow when the valve is open and; where the movement of the key downwards as far as possible should close the valve and permanent fixed notice displayed to clearly indicate when the control is open and shut.; either the means of operating the control should be clearly marked or suitably
Notices for meters and emergency controls

ALL new primary replacement primary meter installations and any ‘Emergency Controls' that are separate or out of site of the meter should have permanent notices prominently displayed, advising consumers/building occupiers to:-
Shut off the supply of gas immediately in the event of an escape of gas into the building.
If gas continues to escape after closing the emergency control, advise the gas supplier as soon as reasonably practicable.
The emergency control is not to be re-opened until the escape of gas has been properly eliminated/ repaired.
The notice must also state:-
The name of the gas supplier.
The emergency telephone number of the supplier.
The date the notice was first displayed.
Where a label/sign is provided near a separate emergency control the label/sign should be headed ‘Gas Emergency Control'.

If a primary meter is installed more than 2 metres from or out of sight of the nearest upstream emergency control, the permanent notice at the meter must also indicate the position of the emergency control.
Meters

No meter shall be installed on or under a flight of stairs or within any escape route in a building with one or more storeys above the ground floor, where the stairway or escape route provides the only means of escape in case of fire, for exceptions see below.

In buildings with two storeys or more above the ground floor existing meters may be replaced in such an escape route and in buildings with only one storey above ground floor, a meter may be installed provided in both cases that:-
The meter installed is of fire resisting construction or;
Housed in a half hour fire compartment with a self-closing door that would prevent the meter being adversely affected should gas escape in hazardous quantities or;
The pipe immediately upstream of the meter and the governor
(if adjacent to the meter) incorporates an automatic shut off valve to shut off the flow of gas if the temperature of the shut off valve exceeds  degrees centigrade.

Gas meters must not be installed where there is a risk of damage from electrical apparatus. A fire resisting partition of electricity insulating material is required if any electrical equipment is mounted within 6 inches.
All meters must be installed so as to be readily accessible for inspection and maintenance.

Where a meter is housed in a meter box attached to, or built into the external face of an outside wall, the housing must be so constructed as to ensure that gas escaping within the box cannot enter the building or any cavity in the wall.
Wherever a lockable meter box is installed, the consumer must be supplied with a key, clearly labelled ‘gas meter box' in black on a yellow background.

The present duty (to display a notice indicating the position of the nearest upstream emergency control when a meter is installed at a distance of more than 2 metres from, or out of sight of that control) is now extended to cases where a meter is relocated in such a position.

The duty to provide a notice where gas is supplied through a service pipe or service pipework to more than one primary meter is now extended to any person subsequently making a modification affecting the number of meters provided. Additionally, the outlet of an emergency control is required to be sealed when a primary meter is removed and notice is required to be given to the gas supplier when such removal is proposed.

The duty under existing Regulation  of the Gas Safety (Installation and Use) Regulations 1998 has been amended to require any person supplying or permitting the supply of gas through a primary meter to a secondary meter (e.g. a gas supplier and/or landlord) to display a line diagram showing the configuration of all meters, installation pipework and emergency controls. Additionally, any person subsequently making a change affecting the accuracy of the diagram is required to ensure that the diagram is suitably amended.
NOTE: The changes outlined above affect only new supplies (or changes in existing supplies), or modifications to existing systems that took place after October 1998.
Flammable materials must not be stored in any meter box.
Governors

Governors installed for regulating the pressure of the gas through a primary meter or its by-pass should be adequately sealed to prevent the settings being interfered with. Seals should only be broken by the gas supplier or any installer authorised by the supplier in writing.
Pipework
Installation pipes should be installed in a safe and workmanlike manner so that any pipes, cables, fittings and structures will not affect their safe use.
Gas pipes in buildings should be bonded to the electrical earthing system.

Gas pipes installed in walls or floors or other solid structures should be protected against failure caused by movement. Pipes passing through such structures should take the shortest practicable route and be enclosed in a gas tight sleeve installed so as to prevent gas passing through the sleeve or between the sleeve and the structure.
Installation pipes should not be installed in the cavity of a wall, in the ground, under foundations or footings, or in any unventilated shaft, duct or void.
NOTE: The space between floorboards and the ceiling below is not considered to be ventilated.
Pipework must not be installed in a way likely to impair neither the structure of the fire resistance of a building or part of it.

Installation pipes likely to be subject to the deposition of any liquids or solids, should be provided with a suitable vessel(s) for the collection of such deposits mounted in a conspicuous and readily accessible position. A safe means of clearing the deposits must also be provided.

Where pipework is installed and purged but not put into immediate use it shall be sealed off at every outlet and every seal tested for gas tightness. Any connection loosened to facilitate purging should also be tested for gas tightness on re- tightening.
All gas pipework not supplied with gas on completion of the installation must be examined and tested for gas tightness and purged before being into use.

When gas pipes are installed in premises other than a dwelling and the pipes are accessible for inspection, they should be permanently colour marked e.g. (yellow ochre) to identify the pipe(s) as a natural gas pipe. The responsible person should ensure that the markings are maintained so that they remain recognisable for the entire duration that the pipe(s) are used for conveying gas.
Pipeline diagrams

Where a gas service (supply) pipe has an internal diameter of 50mm or more and supplies a building with two or more floors or a floor having areas with a separate supply of gas, no person should install an incoming installation pipe unless a valve is installed in a conspicuous, readily accessible position and a permanent line diagram is fixed to the building as near to the primary meter as practicable. The line diagram should indicate the position and size of all pipes of 25mm diameter or more, along with details of meters, emergency valves, pressure test points, condensate receivers and the electrical bonding. Pipes less than 25mm in diameter need not be shown, but the position of branches should be identified.
Gas appliances

No person should install a gas appliance unless the appliance, the means of removing products of combustion, a sufficient supply of air, with the room ventilation and connections to other gas fittings such that their use will not constitute a danger to persons or property. Manufacturer's instructions must be left with the owner or occupier of the premises.
Gas connections to flues of domestic appliances should be by a permanently fixed rigid pipe.
No used or second hand gas appliances should be installed until the installer has verified that it is safe for further use.
No person installing a gas appliance should leave it connected to the supply unless the appliance can be used safely.
No appliance may be installed without a supply shut off valve being provided at the inlet unless the provision of such a valve is not reasonably practicable.

Gas appliances should not be repaired or modified in a way that may make it cease to comply with any type approval or safety standard indicated on the particular appliance. Indications of types of approval or standards should not be defaced or removed.

An examination should be made after servicing domestic appliances to ensure that the flue is effective, there is an adequate supply of combustion air, the appliance is functioning safely and its heat input and operating pressures are satisfactory. Defects must be notified immediately to the responsible person.
No gas appliance should be installed unless the appliance, the gas fittings or flue and all means of ventilation comply with the ‘Building Regulations'.
Gas appliances for installation in a private garage, bath or shower room should only be of the room sealed variety.

Installation pipes may only be used as a suspension support of an appliance if specifically designed for such use and the supporting pipework is constructed and installed in a manner capable of safely supporting its weight.
Flues
Gas appliances should not be connected to any flue unless the flue is suitably constructed and in a proper condition, for the safe operation of the appliance.
Flue pipes should be installed so that they enter any brick or masonry chimney in such a way, as to leave the seal between them visible for inspection.

No gas appliance should be connected to an enclosed flue unless the enclosure is so sealed as to prevent flue gases passing into any room, or internal space other than that containing the said appliance.
Power operated flue systems may only be used where the appliance is prevented from operating if the flue draught fails.
Automatic dampers should be so interlocked with the gas supply as to prevent burner operation if the damper is not fully open.

Manually operated dampers must not be installed in any flue that serves a domestic appliance. No domestic gas appliance should be connected to a flue with a manually operated damper unless the damper is permanently fixed in the open position.
Testing of appliances
No gas should be supplied to newly installed gas appliances other than for testing until the following examinations and tests have been undertaken:-
That the appliance has been installed in accordance with the statutory standard for fittings, gas tightness, flues and ventilation.
The heat input (calorific value of gas) and operating pressure is as recommended by the manufacturer.
The appliance has been installed with due regard to the manufacturer's instructions. All gas safety controls are in working order.
Where adjustments to the installation are found to be necessary to ensure compliance with the above tests and inspections, these must be carried out or the appliance disconnected from the gas supply.
Unsafe appliance

No person should use or permit a gas appliance to be used if that person knows or suspects that there is an insufficient supply of air available for correct combustion, the removal of the products of combustion is not or cannot be safely carried out, the room or space ventilation is inadequate to supply oxygen to occupants, there is any gas escaping or the appliance is so poorly maintained or faulty as to constitute a danger to persons or property.

Any person carrying out work on a gas installation who knows or has reason to suspect that any defect or other circumstance referred to above exists, that person should take all reasonably practicable steps to inform the responsible person or where not practicable the gas supplier.
Liquified petroleum gases (Lpg)
LPG in cylinders

Liquified Petroleum Gas is a light hydrocarbon derivative normally sold commercially as Butane or Propane. It is highly flammable and very hazardous within a 2% and 10% band as a vapour in air mixture. It is heavier than air and may flow along the ground or in drains. The vapour is slightly anaesthetic and may cause suffocation in sufficient quantity. LPG, particularly when in liquid form, can cause severe frost burns due to its rapid evaporation.
Portable cylinder storage of LPG

Only LPG contained in suitable cylinders or pipelines should be present in the work area. The minimum quantity of cylinders should be brought into the area of use, and should be consistent with maintaining continuity of work.

All cylinders other than those in use should be stored either in a safe place in the open air or in ventilated area. Storage areas should be at ground level, not in cellars or basements and should be readily accessible. Permanent notices should be displayed ‘Highly Flammable-LPG' on each point of entry to these stores. Access by unauthorised persons to the storage areas should be prevented.
Storage areas should at all times be kept free of combustible materials and debris.

Cylinders should only be changed by competent persons and care should be taken in their handling; they should not be dropped or allowed to come into violent contact with other cylinders or any other object.

Empty cylinders should be removed as soon as practicable from the area of use and storage or re-filled without delay. Wherever storage of empty cylinders along with full cylinders is necessary, clear segregation of the areas is desirable and suitable notices should be fixed at suitable places to denote the two areas. LPG cylinders should not be stored alongside cylinders containing other gases or hazardous substances without specialist advice.
The outlet valves of all LPG cylinders should be kept closed whilst in storage.
Small scale use of LPG in cylinders
Portable heating and lighting appliances operated by LPG should only be
used temporarily in exceptional circumstances in patient occupied areas as advised in the COP  Part 1-‘Propane Cylinders in Residential Premises'.

Where appliances operated by LPG are used for maintenance work in occupied areas associated with patient care or other residential premises, the maximum size of the cylinder used should be restricted to 15kgs.

Appliances normally using LPG inside a building that is not fitted with a central valve must have an intermediate valve on the hose between the bottle and the appliance. This valve should be fitted to the fabric of the building housing the appliance and the bottle situated outside.
LPG cylinders used for work in occupied areas must be removed to a safe well ventilated storage area at the end of each working day.
Wherever practicable, cylinders and portable equipment should be changed in the open air.
All cylinders should be inspected regularly for any leaks, inspection should NEVER be by means of a naked flame but by one of the following methods:-
By smell.
By the sound of escaping gas.
By the presence of condensation or frosting around the leak.
By applying leak detection fluids over the suspected leaks.
Industrial gases

Industrial gases are used for many purposes such as heating, lighting, burning, refrigeration and purging etc., and the purpose of this section is to ensure that responsible personnel are familiar with the required safety precautions.

The following is a list of industrial gases encountered and used by Trust employee. This list is not comprehensive and care should be taken to observe the manufacturer's instructions when using or working with any type of industrial gas
Acetylene

A highly flammable gas which readily forms an explosive mixture with air. Explosions of this gad develop high pressure and are therefore, more damaging. It is liable to decompose explosively when subjected to heat and shock, even with the absence of air.
Butane and propane

Highly flammable gases, heavier than air, therefore will accumulate at floor level and readily forms explosive mixtures with air. These gases have anaesthetising properties that may be serious in high concentrations, therefore adequate ventilation must be ensured.
Oxygen

A non-flammable gas but when combustible materials are ignited in an oxygen enriched atmosphere, they burn more much more fiercely and sometimes with explosive violence. The gas can be readily absorbed by clothing and in these conditions; a spark or small ignition can result in flash burning. Oil or grease may ignite spontaneously in the presence of compressed oxygen.
Refrigerant gases

Modern refrigeration plant uses chlorinated or fluorinated hydrocarbons in liquid or gas form as a refrigerant. Although the refrigerant may not be flammable, smoking must be prohibited because the vapour of the gas in the presence of heat may decompose to form Phosgene, Chlorine and other toxic substances. Skin contact with liquid refrigerant will almost certainly cause severe burns and should be avoided.
Nitrogen
An inert gas mainly used to purge spaces of flammable or toxic substances and sometimes to prevent the ingress of air.
Hydrogen
A highly flammable gas lighter than air.
General precautions
Cylinders of industrial gases must be stored in suitable areas either in the open air or in well ventilated stores.
Cylinders must be protected from external heat sources and must not be allowed to stand or lie in water.
Oxygen cylinders must be stored at least 6 metres (20 ft) from cylinders containing flammable gas unless they are segregated from the flammable gases by a fire resistant partition.
Acetylene and liquefied petroleum gas may be stored together in safe positions in the open air or in a non-combustible ventilated storeroom.
Gas cylinders and regulators must be kept free of oil, grease and dirt. This is particularly important when handling oxygen cylinders and regulators.
Personnel must not handle oxygen cylinders, valves or any other fittings with greasy hands, gloves or rags.

Gas cylinders must only be changed by trained personnel. During the transportation of industrial gas cylinders, adequate precautions must be taken to prevent them being accidentally knocked over or dropped, particularly if handled by a mechanical handling device. Containers should be secured in cradles, multi-pallets or other suitable framework.

When not in use all cylinder valves must be kept closed. Gas cylinders must NOT be used as rollers, work supports or jacks. Cylinders must be kept away from sparks, flames or slag generated from welding operations.
Use only the supplier's standard keys for operating cylinder valves.
Protective valve caps or covers should be placed in position before pressurised containers are transported.
Gas cylinders may only be changed by trained personnel who will ensure that all cylinder valves are kept closed when the cylinders are not in use.
Portable cylinders when used for heating or welding etc., should be shut off whenever work stops for a significant period, or when the work area is to be vacated for any other reason.
All cylinders must be kept clear of sparks, excessive heat or slag generated during welding and cutting operations.
Cylinders must be removed from the area of use when emptied and stored separately from full cylinders. The cylinders or the storage area must be marked empty/empties to avoid any risk of confusion.

Containers and cylinders must not be used for purposes other than the storage of and supply of authorised gases and fluids. They may, however, support other similar containers in a properly assembled container stack during storage or be used in an appliance where suitably designed.
Design, repairs, maintenance and examination of containers
No attempt should be made to repair or modify pressure containers or cylinders.

The owner of a container/cylinder has the responsibility for ensuring that they are examined by a competent person and clearly marked as tested. They must also be marked to indicate capacity and permitted contents. The Trust must never buy containers/cylinders only hire them, they then have no responsibility for examination, however, it is prudent to keep the minimum number of containers/cylinders on site as practical so that they are periodically returned to the supplier/owner where they will be examined and repaired if necessary.

Transportable gas containers must be provided with such protective devices as may be necessary to prevent danger and are so designed to discharge the contents safely so far as is reasonably practicable. Containers/cylinders designed to contain toxic substances will not be provided with such safety devices.
Storage of cylinders

Medical and non-medical cylinders from these two categories must never be mixed, either in storage or in use. Gas cylinders are sub-divided into groups depending on the major risks associated with the cylinder contents as follows:-
Group  Flammable
Group  Oxidising
Group  Toxic or Corrosive (The contents may also be flammable and oxidising). Group  Others (including inert gases).
Classification of commonly used cylinders

Where a gas falls into more than one category it should be classified according to the primary hazard likely to be encountered in Trust premises, but the storage arrangements must have regard to all its properties.
General principles of cylinder storage The cylinder storage area should be:-
Well ventilated
Clearly labelled
Secure (but with unobstructed access)
Used exclusively for cylinders
For storage of flammable and oxidising gases free from naked flames and all sources of ignition, and in a designated ‘No Smoking' area.
Provided with barriers for cylinder segregation and to prevent cylinders from falling.
Risk assessment programme

At least annually the responsible person(s) will inspect all cylinders and pipelines inclusive of meters, regulators and emergency valves whether in use or in storage and will check the condition of all plant.
The responsible person(s) will check that the pipelines are properly maintained and that no leaks are present.
The responsible person(s) will check that all cylinders in use are properly housed and those in storage are properly secure in designated store areas.
The responsible person(s) must report their findings to the Maintenance Manager with involved costs and a programme of work in priority order to bring the service up to a safe standard.
Securing the health and safety of Trust staff
The Directorate of Estates and Facilities, in consultation with its staff and representatives, will ensure:-
In respect of natural gas, that gas meters, service pipelines and outlets are regularly and safely maintained by a competent 'Gas Safe' registered person.
That the supply pipeline is properly colour coded and free from hazards.
That the units using the gas are properly ventilated and where combustion takes place that the hazardous waste gasses are safely extracted to the atmosphere in the correct manner.
That all equipment using gas is under the control of operators who are aware of this policy and who know what safe action to take whenever a hazard arises.
All gas cylinders are stored, transported and maintained in a safe and proper manner.
Those incompatible gases are not stored together.
Record keeping
An annual risk assessment of all gas services including storage areas, meters, pipelines and equipment using gas services will be carried out.

A log book will be maintained which will include a list and location of all gas meters, cylinders and equipment using gas services. The logbook will record the commencement of use, the regular maintenance and the withdrawal of meters, pipelines, valves and gas appliances.
The logbook will also record the persons who are 'Gas Safe' competent persons.
Training requirements
Adequate on and off site training is provided to the responsible person(s), competent person(s) who maintain or use the gas service or equipment/appliances.

The training will be such that all persons requiring to be trained to 'Gas Safe' registration level shall be so trained and be responsible for the care, use and storage of gas appliances and associated services.

The on-site training will ensure that all persons who have need to use gases in cylinder form or via a supply pipe, are capable of safety using the service and are aware of the precautions to take whenever a hazard occurs.
The responsible person(s) will be trained to be able to properly and safely carry out the annual risk assessment of all gas services and appliances.
All persons who carry out any work in relation to a gas fitting/installation are competent to do so. Proof of competency is best achieved through the 'Gas Safe'
Monitoring and audit

data.text: Approval and implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the Health and Safety Management Group which is the specialist group with the authority to approve local policy and procedure guidelines. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the Health and safety Management Group of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
Equality impact assessment
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.
